nodes.name: Irrecoverable state entry during real-world RL training
aliases: catastrophic unrecoverable states during robot learning
nodes.description: Agents may perform actions that leave the robot or environment in states from which autonomous recovery is impossible, causing safety hazards and halting learning.
nodes.node_rationale: Core risk motivating the paper (Section 1 Introduction).

nodes.name: Limited scalability of real-world RL experiments due to manual reset bottlenecks
aliases: manual reset bottleneck in robotics RL
nodes.description: Frequent need for humans to reset environments stops data collection, limiting experiment length and number of concurrently trained agents.
nodes.node_rationale: The introduction stresses that waiting for manual resets, not data collection speed, is the bottleneck (Section 1).

nodes.name: Insufficient safe exploration mechanisms in deep RL
aliases: lack of safety constraints during exploration
nodes.description: Standard deep RL explores without constraints, easily entering dangerous or unrecoverable regions of the state space.
nodes.node_rationale: Identified as the mechanism causing both safety failures and reset requirements (Section 1, Section 2 Related Work).

nodes.name: High frequency of manual environment resets in RL training
nodes.description: Because agents cannot reliably recover, humans have to reset after every episode or failure, drastically increasing labour cost.
nodes.node_rationale: Described as the immediate operational problem leading to scalability risk (Section 1).

nodes.name: Reversible action sequences ensure recoverability in RL
nodes.description: If the agent’s actions are reversible, it can always return to the start distribution; therefore reversible sequences are treated as safe.
nodes.node_rationale: Authors posit that learning to undo actions removes dependence on manual resets (Section 1, 4.1).

nodes.name: Value function uncertainty estimates improve safety decisions in RL
nodes.description: Estimating uncertainty over Q-values allows distinguishing novel unsafe states from truly safe states when deciding on early aborts.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 4.4 argues that inaccurate Q-values in unseen states can cause unsafe decisions and proposes ensembles to quantify uncertainty.

nodes.name: Joint learning of forward and reset policies for automated recovery
aliases: simultaneous task and reset policy training
nodes.description: Training a task (forward) policy together with a reset policy enables the agent to undo its own actions and eliminates the need to sample from the external initial-state distribution.
nodes.node_rationale: Presented as the central design principle (Section 4).

nodes.name: Ensemble-guided early abort decision design
nodes.description: Use of an ensemble of Q-functions to decide whether to allow the forward action or switch control to the reset policy (optimistic, realist, pessimistic rules).
nodes.node_rationale: Section 4.4 lists three ensemble combination strategies for early aborts.

nodes.name: Multiple autonomous reset attempts strategy to lower manual resets
nodes.description: Before invoking a costly human reset, the agent may try the learned reset policy up to N times, trading off downtime versus risk.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 4.2 introduces parameter N controlling how many failed resets trigger a hard reset.

nodes.name: Tuning early abort Q-value threshold for cautious exploration
nodes.description: Setting the minimum acceptable reset-policy Q-value (Qmin) higher forces more conservative exploration and fewer failures.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 4.1 and experiments (6.3) discuss how threshold choice affects safety and learning speed.

nodes.name: Alternating execution with early aborts restricting unsafe actions
nodes.description: At every step the forward action is executed only if the reset-policy Q-value exceeds Qmin; otherwise control is given to the reset policy, dynamically constraining exploration to recoverable states.
nodes.node_rationale: Algorithm 1 lines 2-6 detail the early-abort gating mechanism (Section 4.3).

nodes.name: Bootstrap ensemble of Q-functions for uncertainty estimation
nodes.description: Maintain multiple Q-networks with different random initialisations; their distribution gives uncertainty estimates used in optimistic/realist/pessimistic abort rules.
nodes.node_rationale: Implementation details in Section 4.4.

nodes.name: Threshold N of consecutive failed resets triggers hard reset
nodes.description: A manual reset is requested only if the reset policy fails for N consecutive episodes, approximating irreversibility without full reachability analysis.
nodes.node_rationale: Algorithm 1 lines 12-14 and Section 4.2 specify this mechanism.

nodes.name: Qmin parameter controlling early abort activation
nodes.description: Scalar threshold: if Qreset(s,a) < Qmin, the forward action is vetoed. Adjusting Qmin changes exploration conservativeness.
nodes.node_rationale: Defined formally in Eq. 1 (Section 4.1).

nodes.name: Simulation experiments demonstrate reduced manual resets with maintained performance
nodes.description: Across ball-in-cup, pusher, cliff cheetah, etc., the method achieved equal or better task reward while halving or better the number of hard resets.
nodes.node_rationale: Figures 4 and 5 summarise core empirical findings (Section 6.1–6.2).

nodes.name: Empirical results: larger ensembles decrease hard resets and increase rewards
nodes.description: With ensemble size 1 the agent failed; ensembles of 10-50 networks both reduced resets and boosted reward (Figure 8).
nodes.node_rationale: Section 6.5 provides quantitative evidence.

nodes.name: Experimental evidence: increasing reset attempts reduces hard resets with minimal reward impact
nodes.description: Raising N from 1 to 4 cut hard resets by up to 2.5× on Pusher while reducing reward by <25%; on Cliff Cheetah resets nearly eliminated (Figure 7).
nodes.node_rationale: Section 6.4 reports this trade-off.

nodes.name: Evidence: higher Qmin reduces hard resets without slowing learning
nodes.description: In the gridworld and continuous tasks, raising Qmin reduced hard resets by up to 78 % with little change in steps-to-solve (Figure 3 & 6).
nodes.node_rationale: Evidence from Section 5 and 6.3.

nodes.name: Fine-tune RL agents with joint forward-reset policies and early abort gating
nodes.description: During fine-tuning/RL phase, simultaneously train a task policy and a reset policy; before each environment step, veto the task action if reset-policy Q< Qmin and hand control to the reset policy.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Core algorithm applied during continuous learning phase (Section 4.3 Algorithm 1).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Validated only in simulation across several tasks (Section 6).
nodes.node_rationale: Primary actionable procedure to mitigate irrecoverable states and manual resets.

nodes.name: Employ bootstrap ensemble of Q-functions in early abort mechanism
nodes.description: Train an ensemble (≥10) of independently initialised Q-networks; use optimistic/realist/pessimistic aggregation rules to decide whether to abort the forward action.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Demonstrated effectiveness in controlled simulation only (Section 6.5).
nodes.node_rationale: Operationalises uncertainty insight for safer exploration.

nodes.name: Set adaptive maximum reset attempts before manual intervention
nodes.description: Permit the learned reset policy up to N consecutive attempts (tuned to task cost) before calling a human or scripted hard reset.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Adjustment is made to the deployed learning loop depending on operational costs (Section 4.2).
nodes.node_rationale: Reduces human resets while bounding worst-case downtime.

nodes.name: Configure conservative Qmin thresholds during training
nodes.description: Choose a higher Qmin value (e.g., 0.4 or 80 depending on scale) to enforce cautious exploration that substantially lowers the frequency of hard resets.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Threshold is typically tuned during pre-deployment safety testing (Section 6.3).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Parameter tuning shows consistent benefit across several tasks, but still lacks large-scale real-world validation.
nodes.node_rationale: Parameterises the safety-performance trade-off for concrete deployments.
